communications.subject: Nebraska Public Records Act Request: Nebraska Medical Board
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Nebraska Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. All physician disciplinary actions from 2019-2024 related to:
   - Mental health conditions
   - Substance use
   - Behavioral health issues

2. Comprehensive physician health program policies, specifically:
   - Approach classification: Punitive vs. Supportive measures
   - Detailed breakdown of intervention strategies
   - Resources allocated to physician wellness programs

3. Detailed statistics on:
   - Self-reported vs. discovered cases
   - Return to practice rates
   - Appeal outcomes
   - Comparative analysis of intervention effectiveness

4. Physician Health Program evaluation documents:
   - Internal studies or reports on program effectiveness
   - Comparative analyses of intervention approaches
   - Confidentiality and support mechanisms

5. Professional Assistance Program details:
   - Formal and informal agreements with Nebraska Medical Board
   - Confidentiality policies and their implementation
   - Reporting protocols (board reporting rates)
   - Physician outcome tracking
   - Long-term support and monitoring strategies

6. Comprehensive program assessments:
   - External and internal program audits
   - Cost-benefit analysis of support programs
   - Physician feedback and satisfaction metrics
   - Comparative analysis with other state approaches

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Vig Sinclair

communications.subject: Muckrock.com Request: 181419-64797971
communications.communication:
Good afternoon,

This letter is in response to an email received by this office requesting certain records pursuant to the "Nebraska Public Records Act," ("NPRA") Neb. Rev. Stat. §§ 84-712 through 84-712.09 (2014, Cum. Supp. 2022). The request is attached to this email for your convenience. For the following reason, the Agency is unable to fulfill this request.

In Nebraska, the basic rule for open public records is set out in Neb. Rev. Stat. § 84-712 (2014). That statute provides, in pertinent part, that "all citizens of this state and all other persons interested in the examination of the public records" shall have the right to examine records in the possession of public agencies during normal agency business hours, to make memoranda and abstracts from those records, and to obtain copies of records in certain circumstances. The request we received for the records listed above came from MuckRock.com. It requires us to respond to MuckRock.com directly, i.e., either by email to MuckRock.com (preferred) or by U.S. Mail addressed to "MuckRock News" in Boston, Massachusetts. However, MuckRock is neither a Nebraska citizen nor an interested person and, as a result, we do not consider this third-party request to be valid under the statute referenced above.

Although no records were withheld due to Muckrock.com's status being not a citizen of the State of Nebraska or an interested party under the NPRA, the Agency provides the following rights to appeal as a convenience:  If you believe the withholding of information requested is in error, you have the right, pursuant to Nebraska Revised Statute § 84-712.03, to appeal the decision by filing for relief by a writ of mandamus in the District Court in Lancaster County, Nebraska or to petition the Nebraska Attorney General for review of this denial. For the purpose of an appeal, Thomas Skutt is the State official responsible for the decision to deny any portion of your request.

Please be advised that public records law allows for a charge for the actual cost of collecting, reproducing, and mailing the records you have requested; however, there is no cost for this request.
Regards,

Thomas Skutt, Jr., JD | Public Records and Discovery Attorney III
LEGAL SERVICES
Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services
OFFICE: 402-471-7020   |   FAX: 402-742-2374
DHHS.ne.gov<http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/default.aspx>  |  Facebook<https://www.facebook.com/NEDHHS/>  |  Twitter<https://twitter.com/NEDHHS>  |  LinkedIn<https://www.linkedin.com/company/nebraska-department-of-health-and-human-services>
CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE: This email message, including any attachments, is for the sole use of the intended recipient(s) and may contain confidential and privileged information.  Any unauthorized review, use, disclosure or distribution is prohibited.  If you are not the intended recipient, please contact the sender by reply email and destroy all copies of the original message.

files.title: attachment-1
files.source: Department of Health and Human Services, Nebraska

communications.subject: RE: Nebraska Public Records Act Request: Nebraska Medical Board
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Skutt:
I appeal the denial of my public records request (#181419-64797971) regarding physician health program records. Your denial based solely on MuckRock's non-Nebraska status warrants reconsideration for the following legal and policy reasons:

Legal Precedent Against Residency Restrictions
Courts have consistently ruled against residency-based restrictions on public records:


McBurney v. Young (2013): While the Supreme Court upheld Virginia's citizens-only FOIA law, it specifically noted this doesn't prevent access through other means or agents
Lee v. Minner (3d Cir. 2006): Struck down Delaware's citizens-only restriction as unconstitutional under the Privileges and Immunities Clause
Lanphere & Urbaniak v. State of Colorado (10th Cir. 1994): Found that once records are publicly available, states cannot restrict access based on residency


"Interested Person" Standard Under Nebraska Law
Nebraska Revised Statute § 84-712's inclusion of "other persons interested" demonstrates legislative intent broader than mere residency:


The research serves compelling public interests in physician health and patient safety
Cross-state comparative analysis benefits Nebraska's healthcare system
National research on physician health programs directly impacts Nebraska medical practices
The information will inform evidence-based policy improvements


Constitutional Implications
Multiple constitutional provisions support broad access:


First Amendment protections for gathering information about government operations (Richmond Newspapers v. Virginia, 1980)
Privileges and Immunities Clause protection for cross-state research activities
Commerce Clause restrictions on discriminating against out-of-state entities


Public Policy and Research Impact
Denying access would:


Hinder research comparing state approaches to physician health
Prevent identification of best practices that could benefit Nebraska
Reduce accountability in programs affecting public safety
Create unnecessary barriers to academic research


Established Research Purpose
This request is part of a comprehensive study of state physician health programs that:


Examines varying approaches to physician mental health and substance use
Analyzes effectiveness of supportive versus punitive interventions
Will produce recommendations for program improvements
Benefits medical professionals and patients nationwide


Practical Considerations
While I could arrange for a Nebraska resident to submit this request, such a workaround:


Wastes state and requester resources
Creates artificial barriers to legitimate research
Contradicts principles of open government
Serves no compelling state interest

I request that you:

Reconsider the denial based on these legal and policy arguments
Process my request as an "interested person" under the statute
Provide a timeline for producing the requested records

If needed, I can provide additional documentation of the research purpose and public benefit. Thank you for your consideration.
Sincerely,
Dr. Vig Sinclair MD
